div.sent: Science is a practical subject.
Science education is not complete without practical experiences.
Once you know the theory and information of science, it is needed to experience the knowledge through experiments and practical applications.
This is the main objective of science education.
If the science education did not have a practical approach, it would be much easier to memorise the theory meticulously.
However, the practical aspect of studying science has made it more interesting as well as useful.
Learning science through practical work makes the learning more sustainable.
A laboratory, apparatus and chemical reagents are essential for the practical work of science.
But in our country there is no laboratory in many schools and there is a shortage of equipments.
But due to shortage of laboratory and equipments one should not stop doing the practical experiments of science.
The idea that we always need well equipped laboratories for practical work of science is not correct.
There are many things around us which can be used to run scientific experiments.
If we are willing and if we have the interest, then we can do many such experiments with simple things which are available around us.
How can we do these?
In this chapter we shall discuss some common laboratory process.
Now the question is what we understand by a common laboratory process?
To learn science and gain knowledge through practical work the methods that we usually use in a laboratory are called common laboratory processes.
There is no mneed of a well furnished laboratory or costly equipment for such experiments.
Only a simple room is sufficient to do this.
Moreover, if any separate room is not available, we can use our class room as a laboratory.
For such simple experiments it is not required to purchase equipments from the market.
If you try, you can also prepare it.
Let us make some simple equipment suitable for using in the laboratory and try to use them.
Various types of apparatuses are needed to work in a laboratory.
All the apparatuses are not always available.
Small parts like delivery tube, connecting rubber tube, jet tube, cork with bores etc. can be made by you in the laboratory.
Objectives: To cut a glass tube of a definite size.
Necessary tools: A triangular file, glass tube, spirit lamp, asbestos, a scale.
Take a clean narrow glass tube and place it on a plain table and hold it pressed by your left hand.
Place an edge of a file on a part of the tube where you want to divide it and draw the file forward and backward.
Take the tube in your hands.
Press gently on the fissure by the thumbs of your two hands.
Bend the right and the left parts towards you.
The glass tube will be divided across the cut mark.
In this way, make pieces of glass tube as many as you need.
The cut ends of the tube are very sharp.
To make them smooth, heat them on spirit lamp and rotate slowly.
When the end of the glass tube becomes red hot then remove it and cool down by keeping it on the asbestos sheet.
Only one mark is to be given in the tube by the file.
Do not touch the red hot end of the tube.
Move slowly the end of the glass tube on the spirit lamp.
Otherwise the tube may crack.
Cut the glass tube to the desired length with a file.
Then put the place where the tube is to be bent hold on the flame.
When the heated tube is soft, it will bend automatically.
Wait until the tube cools down.
Do not touch the heated tube and don't keep it on the table.
Precaution must be taken so that the flame can heat 4-5 cm of the tube.
Care must be taken so that the bending of the tube is uniform.

Objectives: Making a jet tube and necessary parts of a wash bottle.
What is a jet tube?
You have seen the ink dropper.
Jet tube is a glass tube having the shape of a dropper.
One end of a glass tube is broad and another end gradually becomes narrow and turns into a capillary tube.
This type of tube is called a jet tube.
Cut about 10 cm off a narrow glass tube.
Hold the glass tube on the flame of the spirit lamp.
Keep it parallel to the earth surface so that the middle of the tube is placed just above the flame.
Rotate the tube slowly.
Remove the tube when the heated place becomes soft and pull the tube with equal force from both sides.
Thus it becomes gradually narrow at the heated place.
Remember, the tube should remain straight during pulling.
Otherwise, the jet may bend.
The bend should not be pulled forcibly or quickly; other wise the tube may be broken or its mouth may be closed.
Cool the tube on the asbestos sheet.
After cooling divide it at the middle of the capillary portion with a file.
Cut down some portion of the capillary tube if necessary.
Making fine jet is not possible if the heated portion of the tube is not soft enough.
The tube should be pulled uniformly and slowly by holding the two ends at the same level.
Never touch the heated tube.

A cork borer is a combination of some metallic tubes of different diameters.
One end of the tube is very sharp and the other end contains a handle.
Select a suitable cork and wet it in water for 2-3 minutes.
Wet cork is to be compressed with pressing in a squeezer.
Take a borer smaller in size than the hole to be made in the cork and wet the sharp end in water or glycerine.
Keep the cork on the table.
Place its narrow end upward.
Hold the cork on the table with your left hand.
Press the sharp end of the borer with the right hand on the cork where it is to be bored.
Keep the borer upward.
Rotate the borer in right and left directions slowly.
If the rod is slanting, the hole will not be straight.
Until the borer reaches the opposite end of the cork, continue rotating the borer.
Take out the borer when it reaches near the bottom of the cork.
Then turn over the cork and place the borer on the opposite side to complete the bore.
Keep the borer upright.
If boring or is done quickly the cork will crack.
Never bore the cork from the broader end.
In that case the bore may not be straight.

Any liquid changes to vapour when it is heated.
This vapour after cooling down again changes to liquid.
Such a process is called distillation.
Therefore, the processof converting a liquid nto its vapour and then cooling the vapour back into the liquid state is called distillation.
To obtain back salt from its water solution, the solution is heated and water evaporates as vapour.
Salt crystals remain at the bottom of the container.
This process is called vaporization.
In this process solvent or liquid water can not get back, because water vaporizes away.
If both the substances want to get back from solid and liquid or liquid and liquid mixture then distillation process is followed.
Take salt solution in a round bottom flask.
Fit a one hole cork at the mouth of the flask and make it airtight.
Introduce a glass tube bent twice at right angles in the hole of the cork as shown in the figure.
This tube acts as a delivery tube.
Introduce the other end of delivery tube into a test tube and place the test tube in the beaker of ice cold water.
Now heat the liquid of round bottle flask by Bunsen burner or spirit lamp.
Water converts into vapour and pass through the delivery tube.
Thus, distillation is the process by which liquid is first converted into its vapour by heating then converted to liquid by cooling the vapour.
The apparatus shown in figure 6.15 cannot work after some time because the delivery tube and the cold water kept in the beaker become warm.
So vapour does not condense into liquid.
To overcome this problem a special type of apparatus is used for distillation.
This apparatus is known as Liebig condenser which is named after its inventor.
In figure 6.16 the distillation process with Liebig's condenser and in figure 6.17, different parts of Liebig condenser are shown.
Take salt solution in a round bottom flask.
Take up a Liebig condenser.
Introduce the other end of the Liebig condenser into a beaker.
Liebig condenser has two side tubes.
Connect the lower tube with a water tap so that cold water can be injected.
The water leaves out through the upper side tube.
The cool of the condenser will make the vapour liquid again.
It will collect in the receiving beaker.
The liquid collected in the beaker is called liquid residue.
In this way, a solute and solvent can be separated from its solution by distillation process with Liebig condenser.
Camphor, iodine or naphthalene, when kept in open vessels evaporates slowly.
These solid substances when heated change to vapour directly without changing to a liquid state.
They are called volatile substances.
The sublimation process is illustrated by an example below.
Take some mixture of camphor and sugar in a porcelain basin.
Cover this mixture with a glass funnel.
Wrap up the funnel with a wet cloth.
Place the porcelain basin on a wire gauge or a sand bath and heat it gently.
You will see, after a short time, a solid layer of camphor is formed inside the funnel.
The sugar will remain in the porcelain basin.
When other substances are heated, they change to liquid unlike substances like camphor, iodine, ammonium chloride, etc.
